Award.AwardTitle: How Cartilage Works: Unifying Interstitial Lubrication and Hydrodynamics to Explain Joint Function

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Under physiological contact pressures, joint spaces thin as interstitial fluid is driven from articular cartilage. Because cartilage relies on interstitial fluid for its mechanical and lubrication functions, unbalanced exudation necessarily leads to increased friction, cartilage wear, and joint disease. Fortunately, cartilage and joint space actually thicken during physical activity due to the recovery of interstitial fluid in healthy joints. The only, and accepted, hypothesis for this recovery is that "dehydrated" cartilage regions passively uptake fluid when they become exposed to the bath by contact migration. However, recent in-situ studies have shown activity-induced recovery comparable to that observed in-vivo without ever exposing the contact to the bath; the phenomenon is called "tribological rehydration" because it is induced by sliding rather than migration. These preliminary results suggested that the balance between interstitial fluid loss and recovery in active joints is regulated by the interaction between interstitial (within cartilage) and hydrodynamic (between cartilage) pressure fields. The present study tests this hypothesis using explant tribology experiments with in-situ confocal imaging to elucidate the mechanisms involved in tribological rehydration. The anticipated results will help reveal why physical activity is so important to joint health while informing ongoing efforts to design the next generation of bio-inspired joint replacement devices. The investigators will recruit local high school seniors to participate in this research through the University of Delaware College of Engineering's K12 Outreach program.

Recent in-situ studies of cartilage in a convergent stationary contact area configuration have shown that friction decreases with increased speed, which supports the fluid film theory of joint lubrication. However, they also showed that cartilage simultaneously recovered interstitial fluid, which suggests that hydrodynamic pressures serve to restore hydration (via tribological rehydration) and the interstitial lubrication mechanism. Because existing theory relies on contact migration to expose dehydrated zones to the bath for recovery, the result also implies a fundamentally new mechanism by which joints maintain and recover joint space during activity. By quantifying the effects of physiological articulation amplitudes and contact stresses on passive and active recovery of cartilage, directly interrogating the interfacial and interstitial microfluidics associated with active-rehydration via in-situ confocal microscopy, and evaluating the influence of cartilage degradation on the rehydration of cartilage, this study aims to identify the limits of passive recovery and tribological rehydration in the physiological context and elucidate the mechanism underlying tribological rehydration. The anticipated results of this study will provide new insights into joint mechanics, disease etiology, and the design of new bio-inspired joint replacement systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Articular cartilage is a remarkable biological bearing material, it has unmatched slipperiness when hydrated, but easily and rapidly loses its lubricity as the water that makes up ~80% of its mass is driven out of the tissue by loading. In trying to better understand ?how cartilage really works? we began to re-interrogate a benchtop cartilage testing approach first introduced in the 1960?s, the convergent stationary contact area (cSCA) configuration, and in doing so uncovered a wholly unexpected and transformational finding. In the cSCA, static loading drives cartilage compression and loss of lubricity as water is squeezed form the tissue. However, during high-speed sliding, cSCA cartilage regains tissue thickness and lubricity lost to prior loading, a behavior that has important implications for not just our understanding of cartilage function, but joint health. Under this award, our team conducted the initial and pioneering studies of the response of cSCA cartilage to high-speed sliding, and developed the theory of sliding-induced, hydrodynamic-driven ?tribological rehydration? to explain our empirical observations. Over the course of this work, we leveraged the cSCA to study a number of questions regarding not just tribological rehydration, but articular cartilage function more generally. We first investigated the influence of sliding conditions on articulation-driven tribological rehydration, cartilage interfacial fluid dynamics, and solute transport; confirming that sliding-induced tribological rehydration of cartilage is fundamentally a hydrodynamic phenomenon. We then investigated how cartilage tissue geometry, sliding speeds, and bathing solution/lubricant presence influences tribological rehydration and cartilage tribomechanics; demonstrating just how fundamentally critical the regulation and maintenance of high levels of cartilage hydration and fluid load support are to the healthy biomechanical function of tissue?and established the cSCA as having the ability to replicate, over the long-term, remarkable tissue compression and friction behaviors that had previously only been observed in intact joints. Subsequently, we investigated how certain natural, but modifiable environmental factors, such as activity vs. sedentary levels and patterns, body mass/applied pressures, and cartilage injuries alter (or compromise) tribological rehydration and the overall function of cartilage. We found that despite the robust ability of high-speed sliding to positively regulate cartilage hydration and lubricity, increased inactivity, elevated contact pressures, and tissue injuries represent biomechanically detrimental inputs that should be avoided. Additionally, through the use of both standard and comparative tribology approaches, we demonstrated that tribological rehydration is a phenomenon that is universally conserved across cartilage from every animal species we have investigated those far (nine species so far) and serves a chondro-protective role during benchtop testing of live cartilage tissues.

For nearly a century, scientists have used cartilage explant studies to investigate the mechanical and tribological characteristics of articular cartilage (and by extension, the joints). From an intellectual merit perspective, the present work has been highly important to the disciplines of cartilage biomechanics and tribology through its demonstration and characterized of an explant testing approach that permits long-term controlled studies of cartilage biomechanics and mechanobiology under physiologically consistent sliding conditions. This represents a first of its kind for the field and provides for a fundamentally novel platform with which to study the effects of physiological sliding activity on the biomechanical and biological homeostasis of articular cartilage. This work has also uncovered a fundamentally novel mechanism by which the unprecedented function of cartilage explants, and by extension the longevity of articular cartilage in vivo may be explained; a potentially major breakthrough in identifying of ?how cartilage really works?. In total, this works has generated a dozen publications that have not only advanced the state-of-the art of cartilage tribology testing and understanding but have ushered forth new theories to aid the construction of an overarching structure to explain the phenomenal functionality of cartilage.  

This project has broad impacts that go beyond our goal of understanding tribological rehydration in the cSCA. Cartilage injury, degeneration and osteoarthrosis have staggering physical, emotional and economic consequences. The present research lends critical new insights into the role that joint activity plays in promoting health joint biomechanics and explaining the counterintuitive, but convincing observation that moderate joint usage can protect against cartilage wear and OA. As a result, this work can impact broader society by informing how movement and joint activity might be approached as simple strategies for aiding clinicians and rehabilitation specialists in enhancing the longevity of healthy joints and rehabilitating injured joints. Such data is critical to the basic science and medical community?s search for both the cause of joint disease and new approaches to prevent or treat it.
